Location: On NYS 97 Near Entrance To Battlefield
Marker text: After Battle of Minisink Brants Raiders With Their Plunder Forded River Here To Camp At Mouth of The Lackawaxen Creek Opposite
Built By John A. Roebling, Builder of Brooklyn Bridge, To Support D. & H. Canal Aqueduct By Which Boats Crossed Delaware, 1848–98

Location: On NYS 52 About 1 Mile East of White Sulphur Springs
Marker text: Joseph And Ebenezer Hill Came From Conn., 1807 Bought 5000 Acres In Hardenbergh Patent. Joseph Was Captain In War of 1812.
In Robertsonville Now Called White Sulphur Springs 1812

Location: On NYS 52 At White Sulphur Springs
Marker text: Jonathan Bradley Robertson Came Here From Bridgeport, Conn., 1807, When It Was A Forest Wilderness. He Served In War of 1812

Location: On NYS 97 At Mouth of Mill Brook Near Pond Eddy
Marker text: D. & H. Canal Dry Dock And Basin 1828–1898
Named July 4, 1812, By James Newkirk. First Settler, Capt. John Newkirk, Prior To 1776. First School, 1784, Taught By Mr. Campbell.
Site of First Newspaper, First Printing Office, First Circuit Court, And The First Academy In Sullivan County
